deliberation: Examined the prophetic formula "this word came to Jeremiah from YHWH" for figurative features. It treats an abstract 'word' as if it physically 'comes' from God, which is a standard metaphorical/personifying way to describe revelation. No other figurative devices detected in this chronological notice.

deliberation: Considered whether 'all the words that I have spoken to you' might be a synecdoche/metonymy for the whole content of Jeremiah's prophetic career, but this is essentially straightforward language for verbal communication and inscription in this context. No clear figurative expressions stand out.

Identified 'House of Judah' as a metonymic designation for the people/dynasty, not a literal building. Also noted the common Biblical idiom 'each man from his evil way', where 'way' (דֶּרֶךְ) metaphorically depicts one's pattern of life/behavior as a path. Other elements (e.g., 'hear all the evil I am planning') are anthropomorphic but not as clearly figurative in this narrative frame.

deliberation: This verse narrates Jeremiah dictating and Baruch writing on a scroll. The wording is concrete and procedural. Phrases like 'all the words of YHWH' are standard descriptions of divine speech without an additional figurative twist here. No clear metaphor, simile, or other figure detected.

Jeremiah says he is 'restrained' or 'confined' and cannot go to the House of YHWH. In context this appears to describe his actual restriction (whether legal or practical) rather than serving as a metaphor. The 'House of YHWH' here can be taken in its concrete sense as the temple building. No distinct figurative expression singled out.

Looked for figurative language in the instructions about reading the scroll. 'In the ears of the people' is a common idiom for 'in the hearing/presence of', but functions as a routine body-part metonymy. The more salient traditional figure is 'House of YHWH' as a designation for the temple as God's dwelling place.

instances.explanation: Calling the temple 'the House of YHWH' uses 'house' metonymically to denote the building where YHWH's presence is focused and where he is approached in worship.

deliberation: Found three figurative expressions: (1) 'their supplication will fall before YHWH', personifying a plea as an object that 'falls' into God's presence; (2) 'each from his evil way', again using 'way' as a metaphor for life-conduct; (3) the description 'great is the anger and the wrath' of YHWH, which uses anthropopathic metaphor and intensifying language for divine judgment.

deliberation: Narrative description of Baruch's obedience and reading in the House of YHWH. Although 'House of YHWH' is present again, it functions here very much as a conventional name for the actual temple space, already treated figuratively in v.6; no additional distinctive figurative expression is introduced in this verse.

Describes the time, the fast, and the assembled people. 'Fast before YHWH' reflects cultic practice and, within the narrative world, is straightforward rather than metaphorical. No explicit metaphors, similes, or other figures beyond standard ritual phrasing.

This verse situates Baruch in a specific chamber and court, reading 'in the House of YHWH'. Again, 'House of YHWH' is the notable traditional metaphor/metonymy for the temple as God's dwelling-place; other spatial and narrative details are literal.

ground: association of the temple with YHWH's abiding presence
a house indicates where someone lives and can be approached

posture: narrative identification of the sacred venue
instances.explanation: The temple is called 'the House of GOD', a conventional metonymic expression presenting the sanctuary as the dwelling-place of YHWH.

deliberation: Micaiah 'heard all the words of YHWH from the scroll.' This language is straightforward: hearing as auditory reception of recited divine words mediated through the scroll. No explicit figurative expressions beyond the standard notion of 'words of YHWH' as prophetic speech.

Describes Micaiah going down to the king's house and lists officials present. All terminology (house, chamber, sitting) is spatial and literal. No figurative or idiomatic expressions with a clear non-literal sense detected.
Micaiah 'told them all the words he had heard' when Baruch read. This is straightforward report language about speech and hearing, with no metaphor or other figure governing the expression.

Officials send Jehudi to fetch Baruch and 'the scroll from which you read in the hearing of the people.' The idiom 'in the ears of the people' is a common body-part metonymy for 'in their hearing', but functions as conventional phrasing; otherwise the language is concretely procedural.

They ask Baruch to 'sit and read it in our ears', i.e., in their hearing. Again, this is a routine idiom rather than a distinct, elaborated figure. The verse otherwise simply describes reading. No notable metaphor, simile, or personification.

The officials fear when they hear the words and speak of reporting to the king. 'They feared, each man to his neighbor' is an idiomatic wording for mutual alarm, but not functioning as a separate conceptual metaphor; it describes an actual reaction. No clear figurative language beyond such minor idiom.
They ask how Baruch wrote the words. This dialog is about the mechanics of dictation and writing, with no evident figurative or symbolic language.

Baruch explains that Jeremiah read aloud and he wrote the words with ink on the scroll. The terms are concrete and technical, referring to physical actions and materials. No figurative language detected.
Officials advise Baruch and Jeremiah to hide so no one will know where they are. This is literal counsel about concealment, not a metaphorical 'hiding'. No figurative devices found.

They go to the king, deposit the scroll in a chamber, and report the matter. The narrative is straightforward; 'in the ears of the king' is again standard idiom for 'in the hearing of', but not pressed as a figure.

Jehudi fetches the scroll and reads it before the king and officials. Language is descriptive of actual movement and reading. No clear metaphor, simile, or other figure beyond conventional 'in the ears' idiom.

Describes the king sitting in the winter house in the ninth month with a fire burning in the brazier. All elements (winter house, month, fire) are literal narrative details. No figurative language indicated.

Details the repeated reading of columns and the king cutting and throwing pieces of the scroll into the fire until it was finished on the fire. The description is concrete; the destruction of the scroll is literal, not a metaphor. No distinct figurative expressions in the Hebrew wording here.

Notes that the king and servants did not fear and did not tear their garments. While tearing garments is a symbolic act of mourning, the wording describes an actual cultural practice, not a metaphorical tearing. The language itself remains literal.

Certain officials plead with the king not to burn the scroll, but he does not listen. Their 'pleading' and his 'not listening' can be understood literally in this narrative context; these are standard verbs for petition and refusal, not extended figurative images.

The king orders the arrest of Baruch and Jeremiah, but 'YHWH hid them.' Within the theological narrative, YHWH's act of hiding is taken as real divine protection, not a metaphor for coincidence or secrecy. No explicit linguistic figure (metaphor, simile, etc.) is foregrounded.

Again we have the prophetic formula 'the word of YHWH came to Jeremiah' after the burning of the scroll. As in v.1, this treats 'word' as something that comes, personifying revelation and using spatial movement for divine communication.

deliberation: YHWH instructs Jeremiah to take another scroll and write on it the former words. The language about 'another scroll' and 'the first scroll which Jehoiakim burned' is concrete and procedural. No figurative usage beyond that.

The verse quotes Jehoiakim's objection to the prophecy that the king of Babylon will come and 'destroy this land and cause human and animal to cease from it.' The phrase 'human and animal' is a stock pair functioning as a merism for all living creatures in the land, representing total depopulation. The rest of the wording is literal threat.

deliberation: Two figurative elements stand out: (1) 'sitting on the throne of David' uses 'throne' and 'sitting' metonymically/idiomatically for reigning in the Davidic dynasty; (2) 'his corpse shall be cast out to the heat by day and the frost by night' uses the day/night pair as a merism for constant exposure to the elements.

deliberation: YHWH says 'I will visit upon him and upon his offspring and upon his servants their iniquity' and 'I will bring upon them ... all the evil.' The key idiom is פקד על ('visit upon'), a conventional figurative way of saying 'punish' or 'call to account'. 'Bring upon' similarly treats calamity as something carried onto them, but this closely parallels the visiting idiom.

deliberation: Jeremiah takes another scroll; Baruch writes on it all the words of the burned scroll and adds many similar words. This is a factual account of rewriting and adding more content, without metaphorical phrasing. No figurative language detected.
